importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Former President Joe Biden tightened export controls on microchips and added 140 Chinese, Japanese, South Korean, and Singaporean entities to a restricted list, citing national security concerns.
Biden signed an executive order limiting US investments in high-tech sectors like semiconductors, quantum computing, and AI in countries deemed security risks, including China.
Biden restricted US exports of advanced computer chips, especially from Nvidia, to China and other countries to limit access to AI and military-related technologies.
The US government placed restrictions on Chinese semiconductor manufacturing, requiring licenses for Chinese entities to acquire US technology, which limited China’s semiconductor progress.
Trump announced a final deal to find a new owner for TikTok, following earlier efforts to restrict the app due to national security concerns.
Biden restricted access to US semiconductor tools and advanced chips to China, aiming to slow technological advancement in Chinese military and AI sectors.
Trump imposed sweeping 25% tariffs on Chinese goods worth $60 billion, triggering retaliatory tariffs from China and accusations of trade bullyism.
Trump increased tariffs on Chinese products to 25% in May 2019, escalating trade tensions and prompting China’s retaliatory measures.
The US, EU, and Japan formally complained to the WTO over China's rare earth export restrictions, which the WTO deemed 'rash and unfair'.
The US-China trade deficit reached a record $295.5 billion during Obama’s presidency, prompting concerns over economic imbalance.
China expanded export controls on 12 out of 17 rare earth metals and refining equipment, effective December 1, citing US trade restrictions as justification.
Trump announced a 100% tariff on Chinese goods, effective from November 1, in response to China’s rare earth export controls.
Trump and Xi are scheduled to meet in South Korea during the APEC summit, though tensions have raised doubts about the meeting's continuation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The current trade tensions between the US and China peak around this period, with a 100% tariff threat and rare earth export controls triggering global uncertainty in trade relations.
The US and China extended their 90-day trade truce, which began in August 2024, signaling a temporary pause in tariffs after a prolonged tit-for-tat escalation.

A period of sustained US trade restrictions on Chinese tech and semiconductors, including the export of advanced chip-making equipment and microchips, marked by executive orders from both Biden and Trump.
Key developments in US semiconductor export controls and restrictions on AI-related technologies began in 2023, shaping the ongoing strategic competition between the US and China.

keyTakeAways: China has expanded rare earth export controls on 12 out of 17 rare earth metals and refining equipment, citing US restrictions on its maritime, logistics, and shipbuilding sectors as justification.
The US, under President Donald Trump, threatened a 100% tariff on Chinese goods on October 10, 2025, effective November 1, in response to China’s export controls.
China accuses the US of ‘double standards’ and ‘national security abuse’ for targeting Chinese firms, especially in military and technology sectors.
The US and China have a history of reciprocal tariffs, including a 145% to 125% tariff cycle, which was eventually reduced to 30% and 10% in May 2024, with a 90-day truce extended twice.
Both nations are increasingly weaponizing economic interdependence, using trade and technology restrictions to gain strategic advantage.
The rare earth market is critical to global tech and defence industries, with China holding a near-monopoly, making it a central element in trade disputes.
The US and China are preparing for a high-stakes meeting in South Korea in October 2025, amid rising tensions and speculation that export controls are a pre-meeting strategy.
Experts suggest that China has been more strategic and organized in its policies, while the US has struggled with lack of strategic coherence, though it holds more global power.
The US government has restricted access to semiconductors and advanced technology for Chinese firms, especially under Biden and Trump, citing national security risks.
China’s export controls impact not just the US but also global markets, affecting countries dependent on rare earths for technology and defence.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former US President who, in 2025, threatened a 100% tariff on Chinese goods and accused China of trade hostility; also suggested pausing the meeting with Xi Jinping.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump's tariff threats and retaliatory measures are central to the current trade dispute, escalating tensions with China and signaling a potential return to trade war dynamics.

namedEntities.name: Xi Jinping
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: President of China, central figure in diplomatic and trade negotiations with the US.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Xi is the counterpart to Trump in negotiations, and China’s response to US tariffs—such as rare earth export controls—reflects strategic moves aimed at gaining leverage in upcoming talks.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Global economic power with a near-monopoly on rare earth minerals and key technological exports.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China’s rare earth export controls are a major flashpoint in the trade dispute, signaling a shift in its economic and security policy posture toward the US.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: World’s largest economy and global technological leader, implementing trade restrictions and tariffs against China.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US has a long history of imposing tariffs on Chinese goods, including a 100% threat in 2025, reflecting broader strategic competition in tech and supply chains.

namedEntities.name: Rare Earth Minerals
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Critical raw materials used in electric vehicles, smartphones, semiconductors, and weapons.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China’s control over rare earths makes them a strategic asset, and export controls directly impact global supply chains and US defence capabilities.

namedEntities.name: TikTok
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Social media platform owned by Chinese company ByteDance, subject to US national security scrutiny.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US attempted to restrict TikTok due to national security concerns, leading to efforts to find a non-Chinese owner under Trump’s administration.

namedEntities.name: Huawei
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chinese tech giant targeted by US export restrictions, particularly in telecommunications and semiconductor design.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Huawei's exclusion from US technology supply chains exemplifies the broader US strategy to limit China’s technological advancement in AI and defence sectors.

namedEntities.name: Microchips
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Semiconductor components essential for AI, computing, and military technology.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US has restricted access to microchip production tools and designs for China, aiming to slow its technological progress and military capabilities.

namedEntities.name: World Trade Organization (WTO)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: International body that ruled China's rare earth export controls as 'rash and unfair'.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WTO's ruling provided early international legal context for China’s export controls, setting precedent for disputes over trade practices.

namedEntities.name: Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Regional forum where Trump and Xi are expected to meet in South Korea.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The meeting setting in APEC frames the current trade dispute within a broader regional economic summit, highlighting diplomatic stakes.

namedEntities.name: Manoj Kewalramani
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chairperson of Indo-Pacific Studies at Takshashila Institution, India.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provides expert analysis on how both nations have weaponized economic interdependence, framing the conflict as a game of strategic deterrence.

namedEntities.name: Kristin Vekasi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Mansfield Chair of Japan and Indo-Pacific Affairs at the University of Montana.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Offers expert insight into how China’s rare earth controls are seen as pre-meeting strategy and how US policy lacks strategic coherence.

namedEntities.name: US Vice President JD Vance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: US political figure who stated the US has more leverage in trade talks with China.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vance’s comments reinforce the idea of US strategic advantage and caution against escalation in trade talks with China.

namedEntities.name: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: US official who stated Trump’s tariffs may not go into effect until November 1.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bessent’s statement adds context to whether the tariff threat will be enacted, indicating a possible pause in escalation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article details a rising trade conflict between the United States and China, triggered by China's expansion of rare earth export controls in October 2025, which the US attributes to unfair trade practices. In response, US President Donald Trump threatened a 100% tariff on Chinese goods, effective November 1, and accused China of trade hostility. China counters that the US has engaged in discriminatory practices and overreached in national security justifications. The article traces a history of trade wars, including reciprocal tariffs from 2018 to 2024, and previous US restrictions on Chinese tech firms like Huawei and TikTok. Experts argue that both nations are weaponizing economic interdependence, with China adopting a more strategic and organized approach, while the US struggles with coherence. The upcoming meeting between Trump and Xi in South Korea adds diplomatic tension, with analysts suggesting that export controls are a pre-meeting move to gain leverage. The conflict underscores the deepening geopolitical competition in technology and supply chains, affecting global markets and economic stability.
title: Trump’s 100% tariff threat: History of US trade measures against China
